plumbing.searchIntent: plumbing costs, plumber prices, boiler installation cost, bathroom plumbing rates

electrical.searchIntent: electrical costs, electrician prices, house rewiring cost, electrical installation rates

building.searchIntent: building costs, construction prices, extension cost, loft conversion prices

roofing.name: Roofing
roofing.description: Professional roofing services including full replacements, repairs, flat roofing, and chimney work
roofing.searchIntent: roofing costs, roof replacement prices, roofer rates, roof repair costs

painting.searchIntent: painting costs, decorator prices, house painting rates, interior decorating costs

landscaping.searchIntent: landscaping costs, garden design prices, patio installation cost, decking rates

regions.name: Central London
regions.regionalInsights: Central London commands the UK's highest home improvement costs due to ULEZ charges (£12.50/day for non-compliant vehicles), premium parking permits (£150-300/day for trade vehicles), and intense competition for skilled labour. Westminster and Chelsea contractors factor in congestion delays, limited material storage space, and the premium expected by high-net-worth homeowners. Material logistics require careful planning with restricted delivery windows.

regions.name: Greater London
regions.regionalInsights: Greater London boroughs like Croydon and Enfield maintain elevated costs due to proximity to central zones, though slightly reduced from prime areas. Contractors still navigate ULEZ boundaries, moderate parking fees, and strong demand from London's commuter belt. Travel times between jobs remain significant, and material costs reflect London supplier premiums despite being outside Zone 1-2.

regions.name: Birmingham
regions.regionalInsights: Birmingham's status as the UK's second city drives moderate cost increases above the national baseline. The city's extensive urban area creates longer travel times between jobs, while recent HS2 development and urban regeneration have increased demand for skilled trades. Material suppliers serve the broader Midlands region from Birmingham hubs, keeping logistics competitive.

regions.name: Manchester
regions.regionalInsights: Manchester's booming property market and Northern Powerhouse investment have elevated construction costs. High demand for renovations in gentrifying areas like Ancoats and Northern Quarter increases competition for quality tradespeople. The city's compact urban core means efficient job scheduling, though traffic congestion during peak hours impacts daily rates.

regions.name: Glasgow
regions.regionalInsights: Scotland's largest city maintains above-average costs due to strong demand in the West End and Merchant City areas. Scottish building regulations can differ from England, requiring specialist knowledge. Material costs reflect transport from central UK hubs, while skilled trades command premium rates due to competition with Edinburgh's market.

regions.name: Liverpool
regions.regionalInsights: Liverpool's urban renewal and waterfront regeneration drive steady demand for home improvements. The city's compact size allows contractors to serve multiple jobs daily, though popular areas like Baltic Triangle and Georgian Quarter command higher rates. Port access keeps some material costs competitive compared to inland cities.

regions.name: Leeds
regions.regionalInsights: Leeds combines Yorkshire's largest city premium with strong commercial and residential development. The financial district's growth increases demand for skilled trades, while areas like Chapel Allerton and Roundhay see competitive bidding for quality contractors. M1 corridor access facilitates efficient material delivery from national distributors.

regions.name: Sheffield
regions.regionalInsights: Sheffield's hilly terrain and diverse neighbourhoods create varied pricing. Contractors factor in challenging access to properties in areas like Crookes and Broomhill. The city's industrial heritage means abundant local suppliers, though skilled trades for period property renovations command premium rates in suburbs like Ecclesall and Dore.

regions.name: Edinburgh
regions.regionalInsights: Scotland's capital commands high rates due to New Town conservation requirements and strong demand in Stockbridge and Morningside. Listed building consents add complexity and cost to many projects. Contractors compete with commercial work from the financial sector, driving up day rates. Material transport from Glasgow and beyond adds logistics costs.

regions.name: Bristol
regions.regionalInsights: Bristol's thriving tech sector and desirable Clifton and Redland areas create strong renovation demand. The city's hills and Victorian housing stock require specialist skills for complex projects. Proximity to the M4/M5 junction allows competitive material pricing, though skilled trades are in high demand across both residential and commercial sectors.

regions.name: Cardiff
regions.regionalInsights: As Wales' capital, Cardiff maintains moderate premiums due to government and commercial activity in Cardiff Bay. Regeneration projects in areas like Grangetown create steady contractor demand. M4 corridor access supports material logistics from Bristol and beyond. Costs remain below major English cities while exceeding rural Welsh areas.

regions.name: Nottingham
regions.regionalInsights: Nottingham's central Midlands location and strong university presence create steady renovation demand in areas like The Park and West Bridgford. M1 access provides competitive material costs, while the city's compact size enables efficient contractor scheduling. Costs slightly exceed baseline due to city centre parking restrictions and urban density.

regions.name: Leicester
regions.regionalInsights: Leicester represents baseline UK pricing with excellent M1/M69 motorway access for materials. The city's diverse property mix from Victorian terraces to modern estates creates varied work opportunities. Local trade competition keeps rates competitive, while proximity to major distribution hubs maintains material cost efficiency.

regions.name: Coventry
regions.regionalInsights: Coventry's central Midlands position and strong motorway links (M6/M69/M45) create ideal material logistics. Ongoing regeneration and university expansion drive steady contractor demand. The mix of post-war reconstruction and modern development offers diverse project types at competitive baseline rates.

regions.name: Newcastle
regions.regionalInsights: Newcastle's North East hub status creates moderate urban premiums, particularly in Jesmond and Gosforth. The city's regeneration and Quayside development maintain contractor demand. A1(M) access supports material delivery though slight transport premiums apply from Midlands hubs. Costs exceed rural North East but remain below southern cities.

regions.name: Sunderland
regions.regionalInsights: Sunderland's coastal location and A19 access create competitive baseline pricing. The city's terraced housing stock and recent Seaburn/Roker regeneration provide steady renovation work. Proximity to Newcastle contractors creates market competition, while local material suppliers from Team Valley keep costs efficient.

regions.name: Portsmouth
regions.regionalInsights: Portsmouth's island location creates unique logistics challenges with M27 access via mainland bridges. Naval heritage and waterfront properties in Southsea command premium renovation rates. South Coast demand and London proximity (90 minutes) drive costs above baseline. Marine environment requires specialist weatherproofing and corrosion resistance.

regions.name: Southampton
regions.regionalInsights: Southampton's port city status and M27/M3 junction create strong commercial and residential demand. Ocean Village and Bedford Place areas command premium rates. Proximity to London and New Forest drives property values up. Material logistics benefit from port access and motorway networks, though skilled trades face competition from marine and commercial sectors.

regions.name: Brighton & Hove
regions.regionalInsights: Brighton's coastal charm and London commuter appeal (60 minutes to Victoria) drive premium South East pricing. Hove's regency squares and Brighton's Victorian terraces require specialist period skills. A23 access supports material delivery despite challenging seafront access. High property values in areas like Kemp Town and Seven Dials sustain premium contractor rates.

regions.name: Plymouth
regions.regionalInsights: Plymouth's South West peninsula location creates baseline pricing despite city size. A38 Devon Expressway access supports material logistics from Exeter and Bristol hubs. Naval dockyard and waterfront properties drive steady renovation demand. Marine environment requires weatherproofing expertise, while local trade competition maintains competitive rates.

regions.name: Derby
regions.regionalInsights: Derby's central Midlands position with A38/A52/M1 access creates excellent material logistics at baseline prices. Manufacturing heritage and Rolls-Royce presence drive steady residential demand. Mix of Victorian terraces in areas like Darley Abbey and modern estates provides diverse contractor opportunities at competitive rates.

regions.name: Stoke-on-Trent
regions.regionalInsights: Stoke-on-Trent's Potteries heritage and lower property values create below-baseline contractor rates. M6 access provides efficient material delivery from Midlands hubs. The six-town structure and terraced housing stock offer high-volume renovation opportunities. Lower living costs support competitive trade pricing throughout the area.

regions.name: Wolverhampton
regions.regionalInsights: Wolverhampton's Black Country location with M5/M6/M54 access maintains baseline pricing. Proximity to Birmingham creates contractor spillover without premium rates. Industrial heritage and canal-side regeneration drive steady renovation work. Material costs benefit from excellent Midlands distribution network access.

regions.name: Hull
regions.regionalInsights: Hull's East Yorkshire location creates below-baseline rates despite port city status. A63 access supports material delivery though slight transport premiums from Midlands hubs. Recent City of Culture regeneration and Old Town restoration drive contractor demand. Lower property values and living costs maintain competitive trade pricing.

regions.name: Reading
regions.regionalInsights: Reading's Thames Valley position and 25-minute train to Paddington drive South East premium pricing. M4 corridor tech sector and Berkshire wealth create strong renovation demand. Areas like Caversham and Tilehurst command quality contractor rates. Material logistics benefit from M4/M3 access, though costs reflect proximity to London market.

regions.name: Preston
regions.regionalInsights: Preston's Lancashire hub status with M6/M55/M61 access maintains baseline rates. Mix of Victorian terraces in Fulwood and modern estates provides varied contractor work. Proximity to Manchester and Blackpool creates market competition without premium pricing. Material logistics benefit from North West distribution networks.

regions.name: Middlesbrough
regions.regionalInsights: Middlesbrough's Teesside location creates below-baseline pricing despite industrial heritage. A19/A66 access supports material delivery with transport premiums from Midlands hubs. Regeneration projects and Victorian terraced housing drive steady contractor work. Lower property values and living costs maintain competitive trade rates.

regions.name: Swansea
regions.regionalInsights: Swansea's South Wales coastal location maintains baseline rates despite second-city status. M4 access supports material logistics from Cardiff and Bristol. Waterfront regeneration in Maritime Quarter and Mumbles properties drive renovation demand. Lower costs than Cardiff while exceeding rural Welsh areas.

regions.name: Newport
regions.regionalInsights: Newport's M4 corridor position between Cardiff and Bristol creates baseline pricing with excellent material logistics. Recent regeneration around Friars Walk and riverfront drives contractor demand. Proximity to Cardiff and Severn crossing provides market competition. Industrial heritage and modern development offer diverse project types.

regions.name: Luton
regions.regionalInsights: Luton's proximity to London (30 minutes to St Pancras) and M1/M25 access drives above-baseline costs. Airport employment and rapid development in areas like Limbury create contractor demand. Material logistics benefit from motorway networks, though costs reflect South East pressure. Competition with Hertfordshire and Bedfordshire markets maintains elevated rates.

regions.name: Exeter
regions.regionalInsights: Exeter's Devon capital status and M5 access create moderate urban premiums. University presence and cathedral city heritage drive renovation demand in areas like St Leonards and Pennsylvania. Material logistics benefit from M5 corridor despite South West location. Costs exceed rural Devon while remaining below major city levels.

regions.name: Cheltenham
regions.regionalInsights: Cheltenham's Regency heritage and Cotswolds proximity drive premium rates. Period properties in Montpellier and Pittville require specialist conservation skills. M5 access supports material logistics, while affluent demographics and strict planning controls sustain premium contractor pricing. Competition with Gloucester market maintains elevated standards.

regions.name: Bournemouth
regions.regionalInsights: Bournemouth's coastal appeal and retirement/commuter demographics drive above-baseline costs. A338 access to M27 supports material delivery, though coastal location creates slight premiums. Clifftop properties in areas like Westbourne and Southbourne require specialist skills. Marine environment demands weatherproofing expertise at premium rates.

regions.name: Swindon
regions.regionalInsights: Swindon's M4 corridor position between London and Bristol creates moderate premiums. Rapid expansion and new-build finishing work drive contractor demand. Material logistics benefit from A419/M4/M5 access. Proximity to Cotswolds and London commuters elevates costs above baseline while remaining below premium South East levels.

regions.name: Dundee
regions.regionalInsights: Dundee's east Scotland location creates moderate material transport costs from central belt. Scottish building regulations apply throughout. The city's waterfront regeneration and university expansion drive renovation demand. Skilled trades operate at mid-tier rates without the premium pressure of Edinburgh or Aberdeen. A90 corridor supports logistics from Perth and Angus suppliers.

regions.name: Blackpool
regions.regionalInsights: Blackpool's coastal location and tourism economy support baseline contractor rates. Victorian guest house conversions and seafront properties drive renovation activity. M55 motorway access provides material logistics from North West hubs. Marine environment requires specific weatherproofing and corrosion resistance. Seasonal tourism creates variable demand patterns for trades throughout the year.

regions.name: Peterborough
regions.regionalInsights: Peterborough's A1(M) East Coast mainline position provides excellent material logistics. The city's rapid growth creates consistent new-build finishing and renovation demand. Proximity to Cambridge (30 miles) creates moderate cost pressure from spillover demand. Mix of Victorian city centre and modern estates supports diverse contractor work at competitive mid-tier rates.

regions.name: Oxford
regions.regionalInsights: Oxford's university heritage and South East wealth create premium pricing. Conservation areas in Jericho and North Oxford require specialist period property expertise. London commuter demand (60 min to Paddington) elevates property values. M40 corridor supports material logistics. College and commercial work competes for skilled trades, maintaining high day rates year-round.

regions.name: Slough
regions.regionalInsights: Slough's proximity to Heathrow and London (20 miles) drives South East pricing despite the town's commercial focus. M4/M25 access provides excellent material logistics but also creates congestion. Contractors charge rates reflecting Berkshire and West London competition. Growing residential development and business park conversions create steady demand for trades.

regions.name: York
regions.regionalInsights: York's historic city status creates unique dynamics with extensive conservation areas requiring specialist expertise. Medieval and Georgian properties demand period-appropriate skills and materials. A64/A1(M) access supports logistics, while tourism and heritage sectors maintain steady contractor demand. Skilled trades command moderate premiums for conservation work, though not reaching major city levels.

regions.name: Cambridge
regions.regionalInsights: Cambridge's university prestige and Silicon Fen tech wealth create premium market dynamics. Conservation areas around colleges demand specialist heritage skills. London commuter demand (50 min to King's Cross) drives high property values in Newnham and Trumpington. M11 corridor supports excellent material logistics. College and commercial sectors compete heavily for skilled trades, maintaining premium rates.

regions.name: Ipswich
regions.regionalInsights: Ipswich's East Anglian location maintains baseline pricing with A12/A14 access for materials from Eastern region hubs. The town's Victorian and Edwardian terraces provide straightforward renovation projects. Waterfront regeneration drives new development work. Local trades operate at competitive baseline rates, with limited pressure from Cambridge and Norwich markets.

regions.name: Birkenhead
regions.regionalInsights: Birkenhead's Wirral location across from Liverpool maintains baseline rates despite proximity to the city. Victorian terraces and waterfront areas provide steady renovation work. Mersey tunnels can add travel time but contractors serve both Wirral and Liverpool markets. M53 access supports material delivery from North West hubs. Competitive baseline pricing reflects regional market dynamics.

regions.name: Telford
regions.regionalInsights: Telford's 1960s new town status means predominantly modern housing with minimal period property complexity. M54 junction access provides excellent material logistics from Midlands distributors. The town's planned layout enables efficient contractor scheduling. Baseline rates reflect competitive Shropshire market, with proximity to Birmingham and Wolverhampton creating limited cost pressure.

regions.name: Gloucester
regions.regionalInsights: Gloucester's M5 corridor position supports cost-effective material delivery from South West and Midlands hubs. The city's docks regeneration and cathedral quarter create varied renovation projects. Victorian terraces and modern estates provide steady contractor work. Baseline rates apply despite proximity to Bristol and Cheltenham, with competitive local trades market.

regions.name: Watford
regions.regionalInsights: Watford's Metropolitan Line connection to London (20 minutes to Baker Street) drives South East premium pricing. M1/M25 access creates excellent material logistics but also attracts London contractor rates. The town's Victorian and Edwardian areas in Nascot Wood require period skills. Competition with North London and Hertfordshire markets maintains elevated day rates.

regions.name: Colchester
regions.regionalInsights: Colchester's Essex location maintains baseline pricing with A12 access to London and Ipswich. Roman heritage and garrison town status create diverse property types from Georgian terraces to modern developments. University expansion drives student accommodation renovations. Local trades operate at baseline rates, though some London influence exists in commuter villages.

regions.name: Bath
regions.regionalInsights: Bath's UNESCO World Heritage status creates unique premium dynamics. Georgian architecture throughout the city requires specialist conservation skills and Bath stone expertise. Strict planning controls and listed building consents add complexity and cost. M4 corridor access supports logistics. High property values and wealthy homeowner base drive premium contractor rates, with period-appropriate craftsmanship commanding top prices.

regions.name: Milton Keynes
regions.regionalInsights: Milton Keynes' M1 corridor position between London and Birmingham drives above-baseline rates. The new town's grid system enables efficient contractor logistics, while rapid expansion creates consistent demand. Proximity to London (35 minutes to Euston) influences property values. Material delivery benefits from excellent motorway access via M1/A5.

regions.name: Aberdeen
regions.regionalInsights: Aberdeen's North Sea oil heritage creates elevated costs despite recent industry downturn. Specialist granite property skills command premium rates. Scottish building regulations and isolated location create material transport premiums. Skilled trades maintain high day rates due to commercial sector competition. A90 corridor supports logistics from central Scotland.

regions.name: Norwich
regions.regionalInsights: Norwich's Norfolk capital status and historic centre create moderate premiums. Cathedral quarter and Georgian properties require period skills. A11/A47 access supports material logistics despite East Anglian location. University and commercial sectors drive steady renovation demand. Costs exceed rural Norfolk while remaining below major city levels.

regions.name: Canterbury
regions.regionalInsights: Canterbury's UNESCO World Heritage status and cathedral city heritage drive premium rates. Extensive conservation areas require specialist medieval and Tudor expertise. London commuter demand (55 min to St Pancras) elevates property values. A2/M2 access supports material delivery. Listed building work and tourism sector maintain elevated contractor pricing.
